body.name: ASUS ROG Strix B650E-E Gaming WiFi AM5 (LGA1718) Ryzen 7000 Gaming Motherboard(16+2 Power Stages,DDR5,4X M.2 Slots, PCIe® 5.0, WiFi 6E, 2.5G LAN,USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 Type-C® Rear I/O Port, Aura Sync RGB)
body.merchantInfo: Ships from and sold by TradePort.
features: AMD Socket AM5: Ready for AMD Ryzen 7000 Series desktop processors
Robust Power Solution: 16 + 2 teamed power stages with dual ProCool power connectors, high-quality ally chokes and durable capacitors to support multi-core processors
Optimized VRM Thermals: Massive heatsinks with strategically cut airflow channels and bonded to the power stages with high conductivity thermal pads
Next-Gen M.2 Support: Two PCIe 5.0 M.2 slots and two PCIe 4.0 M.2 slots all covered with heatsinks to maximize performance
Abundant Connectivity: USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 Type-C port and front-panel connector, eleven additional USB ports, two PCIe 5.0 x16 SafeSlots, HDMI 2.1, and DisplayPort 1.4
body.description: ASUS ROG STRIX B650E-E GAMING WIFI motherboard is built for gamers who pursue optimal in-game experience with boosted power delivery and an optimized cooling design to maximize the demand for Ryzen 7000 series processors. Along with the latest Wi-Fi 6E, DDR5 Memory, and PCI Express® 5.0 for superfast data transfer, memory, and storage performance, ROG STRIX B650E-E GAMING WiFi is unmistakably ROG with its futuristic design elements, iridescent ROG logo, monochrome finish and Aura lighting that will give your build a subtle but vibrant look.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Perfectly Good motherboard so far..
reviews.reviewText: Works great, I was a bit worried about receiving a bad board, but it turned out great. The board works perfectly fine for me with no issues so far.Totally would recommend this board.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2023
reviews.reviewText: It didn’t work with my old psu 850 rmx corsair 2017I had to buy a new one and after that was greatIt work with 7800 3DI updated the biosNo issue with expo but I did research to make sure the ram was fully compatible some model even if are expo are not compatibleBoot time is not super fastBut overall happy

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 1.0 out of 5 stars DO NOT BUY ASUS AM5
reviews.reviewText: Ram configurations don’t work in expo, so I sent it for rma. Got someone else’s refrebished board which was delivered DOA…. Asked support to fix this and they’re just sending me through endless support loops. They also request that you pay shipping ~60$ each time they send you another broken part. Save the headache and AVOID this POS!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Plenty of USB and other inputs
reviews.reviewText: This thing runs what I need to with the correct amount of RAM. Installation is pretty straightforward if you have any PC building skills for what I use it for, it does it all. I’m not a big gamer but it runs all the programs I need.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Impressive features that match many X670E motherboards.
reviews.reviewText: Received on January 27, 2023. Will update this review as needed.-----Update as of May 26, 2023.-Asus has done some damage control and have clarified that for they will cover the warranty for B650 and X670 motherboards even if you use EXPO or a beta bios - new bios versions are also available. However, I am not changing my review rating as the situation was still handled very poorly and my rating reflects that as it involves this product/motherboard.-----Update as of May 5, 2023.-TLDR for this update:Don't buy an Asus motherboard for Zen 4 (7000 series CPUs). Look elsewhere at brands like MSI, Gigabyte or ASRock.If you already own an Asus board, update your bios and check your voltage. Limit it manually if possible.-Unfortunately, despite the features and good price point for its features (compared to the market), I can't exactly recommend this motherboard or any Asus motherboard for AM5 Zen4 CPUs.Please refer to Gamers Nexus for more technical information regarding the issues affecting Asus motherboards and more details about Asus' poor handling of the situation.In short, Asus had a faulty bios that caused issues to Zen4 CPUs by feeding them more voltage than needed when EXPO profiles were enabled. This is a much bigger issue for X3D CPUs but it doesn't mean non X3D are unaffected. This sort of thing will impact the lifespan of your CPU as running at the unnecessarily high voltages is very demanding and causes physical degradation of the silicon.In my case, I undervolted my CPU but I would imagine most users did not. Asus' then delivered beta versions of their bios that promised to fix this issue at the cost of waiving your warranty for using a beta version. (and it didn't even fix the issue) This is very disappointing and I can no longer trust Asus after seeing how they handled this. Their recommendation to disable EXPO is shortsighted and senseless as doing this will negatively impact your CPUs performance in a big way as well as possibly cause instability on some RAM sticks. Asus is no longer the quality premium brand it pretended to be.Even if your CPU is not dead yet, any damage done to your CPU for running at such high voltage is already there and it is permanent.-----I am currently using this with my Ryzen R9 7900X and have not experienced any issues. It boosts properly and its performance is stable with CL30 memory clocked at 6000Mhz.It offers Gen5 PCIe and Gen5 m.2 so you can future proof your system if you ever intend to upgrade to a new GPU (current 40 and 7000 series GPUs are only Gen4 so don't worry about it for now). Likewise with the m.2 slots, it supports Gen5 so you can also upgrade your storage when needed.It is an 8 layer board with excellent power delivery so it's got your basic overclocking needs covered as well.Either this or the B650E AORUS MASTER which offers very similar features/specs at the same price point are great options, I highly recommend checking out the full specs of both and see which one offers what you want.Also remember this, motherboards will not really make much of a difference for gaming so you can avoid overspending on this to increase your budget elsewhere. Buy them based on the features you want and if you are an avid overclocker who wants the absolute best, you should probably look at the X670E boards instead.This board also has Clear and Reset CMOS options, which is an excellent feature if you ever mess up anything in the bios. You can always use that to go back to the base stable settings or install a fresh bios. It also has a Q-Code display for basic troubleshooting if your system is ever not booting properly.Keep in mind that you can only use 3x m.2 drives if you want PCIe Gen5 on the first PCIe slot. Using other PCIe slots may also lower the bandwidth to Gen4 on the first one depending on the amount of lanes used.Overall, with this board you are gonna get similar features to that of the mid-high X670E boards at a much lower price and not have any sort of performance issues, while at the same time, futureproofing your system so you can drop in a new gen5 GPU or gen5 m.2 storage in a few years.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This is the first time I build a PC that everything I purchased worked out of the box!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 2.0 out of 5 stars Very hard to set up!
reviews.reviewText: Once you get this working, it works well. But getting it working can be a huge headache. By default this motherboard will not recognize legacy boot drives (this can be enabled in BIOS), none of the drivers required are easily available, and until they are properly installed this motherboard is very unstable (as in, expect BSOD every few minutes).If you are planning to use this for a Windows PC, then there are two options to easily get it working, but before you start I strongly recommend downloading the chipset, ethernet, and WIFI drivers from the ASUS website and keeping this somewhere safe. But those two methods:1: Use a HDD with an existing and fully updated version of windows (you may need to set CSM to enable legacy boot media in BIOS).2: Before you start, download a new version of Windows 11 and make a boot USB. When loading windows YOU MUST have a mobile device capable of USB tethering so you can use the internet (the onboard WIFI and LAN are disabled until you manually install the drivers from the ASUS website).*Hint: You Must run windows update before you can install the LAN/WIFI drivers which you need to run windows update.I spent two days fighting with this motherboard trying to solve instability, get past various POST errors, and get basic drivers loaded. Now that it's done I'm happy with the board. This is not an expensive motherboard, but getting here was not worth the savings.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good Quality Board. Its the x670 version with slight lower VRMs
reviews.reviewText: Was a GREAT motherboard but wound up returning it because I changed to the 13900k

reviews.reviewTitle: Otra tarjeta madre rota aver si no viene dañado como la otra
reviews.reviewText: The media could not be loaded.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motherboard is really good, but the BIOS could be better
reviews.reviewText: The quality of the materials for the motherboard is really good. Must warn anyone that intends on buying AM5 motherboards, make sure to flash your BIOS to the latest version prior to doing any setup of OS and further use for stability reasons.The Q-Code appears to be more useful on Asus boards due to the number of potential issues you can encounter.I was able to get the motherboard posting immediately after installing all parts, but ran into a few minor issues, mainly ram seating issues. After ram was fully secured in, there wasn't any present issues. The latest BIOS made it more stable than previous comments throughout the internet, but there's still work to do for the BIOS.By default, Disabling Memory Context Restore and Enabling Fast Boot will make your post to loading OS roughly over 40 seconds every time you turn on the computer. Owners of this board will need to make their own adjustments to fasten post to load time.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you are buying it from Australia, dont is comes from US and lot of delays.
reviews.reviewText: Receive it after 2 weeks, Constant usb overcurrent warning and reboot. Won't even past the POST screen. Put it on refund and sent back very next day. It's been almost 3 weeks. Still status saying it's in Amazon fulfilment center waiting to be processed and no refund given.AUS customers please buy from local store as RMA process with asus doesn't apply for Amazon global store. If it doesn't work you have to send it back to US and wait for weeks to be refunded. Better buy locally and save yourself some headache.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice PCIe ports, but bad LAN/Wifi/Bluetooth
reviews.reviewText: Works very well on Linux (Debian/Ubuntu based). Very good overall, but LAN drop every now and then (not a Linux issue). I worked around by buying a PCIe ethernet adapter. Bluetooth sometimes stop working after a reboot or something like that. I have to power off/power back on to make it work again. It's reliable while connected and doesn't drop though.
